Article Title: Thanksgiving 2025: Retailers Closed, Record Travel Forecast, and Black Friday Openings
Article Text:
Retail, banks and deliveries halted for the holiday

AAA projects 81.8 million Thanksgiving travellers

Americans are set for a mix of family meals and early holiday shopping this week, with most big retailers staying shut on Thanksgiving before reopening at dawn for Black Friday, the unofficial start of the Christmas buying rush. The week also marks what AAA says will be the busiest Thanksgiving travel period on record, according to AP report.Most national retailers — including Walmart, Target, Macy’s, Kohl’s and Costco — will remain closed on Thursday, returning with early openings from 5 a.m. or 6 a.m. on Black Friday. CVS will shut early, and Walgreens will close most stores except select 24-hour locations. Grocery chains will open but many will close ahead of schedule, with timings varying by area.Government offices, post offices, courts and schools will be closed. US banks and stock markets will also shut for the day, reopening on Friday for a shortened trading session that ends at 1 p.m. Eastern. Standard FedEx and UPS pickup and delivery services will not operate on Thursday, though limited critical services will be available at certain locations.With schools closed and a long weekend ahead, travel is expected to surge.AAA estimates that 81.8 million people will journey at least 50 miles between Nov. 25 and Dec. 1 — 1.6 million more than last year and a potential new record. Nearly 73 million will travel by car, aided by petrol prices holding near $3 a gallon, slightly below last Thanksgiving’s average.About 6 million Americans are expected to fly domestically, a 2% rise from 2024, though cancellations or delays could shift the final count. Another 2.5 million travellers will rely on buses, trains or cruise ships, marking an 8.5% increase from last year.For many households, Thursday offers a quiet holiday — before the weekend turns into one of the year’s busiest on the roads, at airports and at shop entrances.
Article Summary: AAA projects 81.8 million Thanksgiving travellers. Walmart, Target, Macy's, Kohl's and Costco will remain closed. CVS will shut early, and Walgreens will close most stores except select 24-hour locations. Grocery chains will open but many will close ahead of schedule.

Article Title: Labour reform: New codes to lift consumption by Rs 75,000 crore; SBI sees sharper formalisation ahead
Article Text:
Explained: How new labour laws could hit your take-home salary, increase your provident fund & gratuity contributions

Implementation of the new labour codes is expected to deliver a Rs 75,000-crore consumption boost and raise the share of the formal workforce by at least 15 per cent, according to a research note by economists at SBI on Tuesday.The four codes, enforced from November 21, will also expand social security coverage to up to 85 per cent within the next three years and help reduce the unemployment rate by 1.3 per cent over the medium term, the note said, PTI reported.“With a saving rate of approx 30 per cent, the implementation will result in a consumption boost Rs 66 per person per day post-implementation. This could lead to an approx consumption boost of Rs 75,000 crore,” the SBI economists said.They added that the new framework will empower both workers and enterprises, creating a labour market that is “protected, productive and aligned with the evolving world of work.”SBI economists said India has around 44 crore unorganised workers, of whom 31 crore are registered on the e-Shram portal.Assuming 20 per cent of these workers transition into the formal payroll system, nearly 10 crore people would benefit — pushing social security coverage to 80–85 per cent in the next two to three years.Citing the Periodic Labour Force Survey, the note said 60.4 per cent of India’s workforce is currently formal. The bank expects formalisation to rise by 15.1 per cent under the new regime.The impact on unemployment will depend on “reform implementation, firm-level adjustment costs, and complementary state-level rules,” the report said.
Article Summary: The four codes, enforced from November 21, will expand social security coverage to up to 85 per cent within the next three years. SBI economists said India has around 44 crore unorganised workers, of whom 31 crore are registered on the e-Shram portal. The bank expects formalisation to rise by 15.1 per cent under the new regime.

Article Title: Atmanirbhar Bharat boost for rare earths! Cabinet clears Rs 7,200 crore scheme for manufacturing rare earth permanent magnets
Article Text:
‘Good Policy In Place’: Rare Earth Expert On India’s National Critical Minerals Mission

Rare Earth Permanent Magnets Scheme: Top Points

To promote manufacturing of sintered Rare Earth Permanent Magnets

Focus on value chain: integrated manufacturing facilities, conversion of rare earth oxides to metals, metals to alloys and alloys to finished REPMs

Investment: Rs 7,280 crore

Creating capacity of 6 thousand Metric Tons Per Annum (MTPA)

5 units of 1,200 MTPA capacity to be set up

Scheme duration: 7 years including 2 years for setting up manufacturing unit

India bets on Atmanirbharta for rare earths! In a boost to India's domestic rare earth manufacturing capabilities, PM Narendra Modi-led Union Cabinet on Wednesday cleared an over Rs 7,200 crore Rare Earth Permanent Magnets (REPM) Scheme. The scheme aims to establish integrated manufacturing facilities with a capacity of 6,000 Metric Tons per Annum (MTPA) of Rare Earth Permanent Magnets. The initiative hopes to strengthen India's self-sufficiency and global market presence.REPMs, believed to be amongst the most powerful permanent magnets available, serve as essential components in various sectors including electric vehicles, renewable energy, electronics, aerospace and defence industries. Currently dependent on imports for REPM needs, this initiative marks India's first integrated REPM manufacturing facilities, creating jobs, enhancing self-sufficiency and supporting the country's Net Zero target by 2070. The scheme includes Rs 6,450 crore as sales-linked incentives for REPM sales over five years, alongside Rs 750 crore capital subsidy for establishing 6,000 MTPA of REPM production facilities.Announcing the decision, Information and Broadcasting Minister Ashwini Vaishnaw stressed on the strategic importance of the initiative ,which is a first-of-its kind. “This is a very important, strategic decision,” he said. According to Vaishnaw India has one of the largest rare earth deposits in the world.At present, India remains significantly dependent on imports of rare-earth permanent magnets, with China being the main source. The scheme is part of India’s comprehensive strategy to establish secure supply chains for essential minerals whilst developing domestic technological capabilities in emerging industrial domains.The approved scheme will facilitate the development of comprehensive REPM manufacturing units that will oversee the entire process from converting rare earth oxides into metals, transforming metals into alloys, and finally producing finished REPMs.India expects a twofold increase in REPM consumption by 2030 compared to 2025, primarily due to higher demand from electric vehicles, renewable energy, industrial sectors and consumer electronics.Through a global competitive bidding procedure, the scheme plans to distribute the total capacity among five recipients. Each selected recipient will receive an allocation of up to 1,200 MTPA capacity.The scheme's implementation spans seven years from the award date, incorporating a two-year establishment period for integrated REPM manufacturing facilities, followed by five years dedicated to disbursing incentives for REPM sales.The scheme's focus on developing local REPM production expertise will ensure a secure supply chain for national industries and contribute towards achieving the country's Net Zero 2070 targets.
Article Summary: The scheme aims to establish integrated manufacturing facilities with a capacity of 6,000 Metric Tons per Annum (MTPA) of Rare Earth Permanent Magnets. The initiative hopes to strengthen India's self-sufficiency and global market presence. The scheme's focus on developing local REPM production expertise will ensure a secure supply chain for national industries.

Article Title: US labour market holds firm: Jobless claims fall to 216,000; layoffs stay low despite corporate cuts
Article Text: Fewer Americans applied for unemployment benefits last week, signalling continued stability in the labour market even as several large companies announced job cuts. According to AP, jobless claims fell by 6,000 to 216,000 in the week ending November 22, undershooting economists’ expectations of 230,000.Applications for unemployment aid — a key proxy for layoffs — remain at levels consistent with a healthy job market. AP reported that job cuts disclosed by companies such as UPS and Amazon typically take longer to show up in weekly claims data. The four-week average of claims eased by 1,000 to 223,750.For now, the US labour market appears to be in a “low-hire, low-fire” phase, keeping unemployment historically low but slowing the pace at which jobseekers find work. The number of Americans receiving jobless benefits rose by 7,000 to 1.96 million in the week ending November 15, suggesting longer job searches.Government data last week showed hiring picked up modestly in September with employers adding 119,000 jobs, though August saw job losses. The unemployment rate edged up to 4.4%, a four-year high, as more people re-entered the workforce.Retail sales slowed in September after three months of solid gains, while consumer confidence slipped to its second-lowest level in five years and wholesale inflation eased. The latest figures point to cooling economic activity and waning price pressures, lifting market expectations that the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates at its next meeting on December 9–10.
Article Summary: Jobless claims fell by 6,000 to 216,000 in the week ending November 22, undershooting economists’ expectations of 230,000. Job cuts disclosed by companies such as UPS and Amazon typically take longer to show up in weekly claims data. For now, the US labour market appears to be in a ‘low-hire, low- fire’ phase.

Article Title: Income Tax ‘nudge’ for 25k cases of unreported foreign assets, income
Article Text:
‘Second NUDGE’ to advise people to review their returns by Dec 31

NEW DELHI: The income tax department has launched a fresh campaign to nudge those with overseas assets or income to disclose details in India. Initially, around 25,000 high-risk cases will be targeted through SMS and e-mails, with the campaign proposed to be expanded mid-Dec to cover others, and improve the compliance ecosystem.The initiative comes exactly a year after a similar move led to nearly 25,000 taxpayers disclosing Rs 29,000 crore overseas assets and income of Rs 1,090 crore.Following analysis of data for 2024, from other tax jurisdictions, Central Board of Direct Taxes has identified high-risk cases in which foreign assets seem to exist, but have not been reported in FY 2024-25 I-T returns, a statement said.The “second NUDGE campaign” will advise taxpayers to review and revise their returns by Dec 31 to avoid penal consequences. “The campaign aims at facilitating correct reporting in Schedule Foreign Assets and Foreign Source Income (FSI) in ITRs. Accurate & complete disclosure of foreign assets and income is a statutory requirement under the Income Tax Act, 1961, and the Black Money (Undisclosed Foreign Income and Assets) and Imposition of Tax Act, 2015,” CBDT said.The Black Money Act has prescribed penalty of Rs 10 lakh for non-disclosure of overseas assets apart from tax of 30% and penalty of 300% on the taxable amount.The income tax department has assessed around 1,080 cases, raising demand of Rs 40,000 crore till June 2025.Searches were also conducted in Delhi, Mumbai & Pune, based on data received on investments in Dubai, unearthing undisclosed foreign assets and income worth several hundreds of crores, an official said. Tax officials said that as part of the campaign, large companies whose employees have foreign assets and have not disclosed them are also being onboarded to sensitise taxpayers. Industry bodies, Institute of Chartered Accountants of India, and other associations have been requested to create awareness.
Article Summary: The initiative comes exactly a year after a similar move led to nearly 25,000 taxpayers disclosing Rs 29,000 crore overseas assets and income of Rs 1,090 crore. The ‘second NUDGE campaign’ will advise taxpayers to review and revise their returns by Dec 31 to avoid penal consequences.

Article Title: Sensex hits 86k, new high in over a year
Article Text: MUMBAI: A rally on Wall Street, rate cut hopes in the US and in India, and strong buying momentum by domestic funds all pushed the sensex above the 86k mark for the first time on Thursday morning. However, profit-taking at higher levels brought the index down from the intraday peak of 86,056 points to close at 85,720, up 111 points on the day.Nifty too followed a similar path. It touched a new life-high mark at 26,310 points in early trades but closed at 26,216 points. Both the indices are at all-time high levels on a closing level too. It took both the indices 14 months to scale new levels.The recent rally has been reinforced by expectations of rate cuts from both RBI and the US Federal Reserve — a shift that improves visibility for interest-rate-sensitive sectors and could trigger renewed foreign fund inflows, Ajay Menon, MD & CEO (wealth management), Motilal Oswal Financial Services, said.Combined with these factors, early signs of a corporate earnings recovery from the current quarter, supported by GST rationalisation and improving rural demand, optimism around a potential trade agreement between the US and India has further strengthened investor sentiment, Menon said.The day’s rally, however, was concentrated in large cap stocks with BSE’s midcap and smallcap indices, both closing in the red.As a result, investors’ wealth, represented by BSE’s market capitalisation, for the day slid slightly—from Rs 474.9 lakh crore on Wednesday, it was at Rs 474.3 lakh crore at Thursday’s close, official data showed.In Thursday’s market, among the 30 sensex constituents, the advance-decline ratio was equally balanced with 15 winners to 15 losers. In the broader market, however, the ratio was skewed in favour of the laggards—compared to 1,936 advances, there were 2,220 declines, BSE data showed.The rally that took the sensex to a new high, started in Oct when the sensex was at about 80,200 points. Since then, in Oct, foreign funds had turned net buyers after three months of net outflow. The last leg of the sensex rally, however, came despite a record-low rupee against the dollar and a marginal net outflow by foreign funds. Market players say this demonstrates that domestic funds, flush with flows through the mutual fund SIP route, most of which goes into equity schemes, have been the main driver of the rally.Market participants would keep a close eye on India’s GDP data for the Sept quarter (set to be announced on Friday), as well as key triggers such as US–India trade deal and RBI policy announcement on Dec 5, a note by Bajaj Broking said.
Article Summary: Nifty too followed a similar path. It touched a new life-high mark at 26,310 points in early trades. Both the indices are at all-time high levels on a closing level too. It took both the indices 14 months to scale new levels.

Article Title: Economy enters H2 on stable footing: Finance ministry
Article Text: NEW DELHI: The economy enters the second half of FY26 on a stable footing, anchored by well-contained inflation, resilient domestic demand and supportive policy dynamics, even as global uncertainties warrant continued vigilance, a finance ministry report said on Thursday.The monthly report for Oct also cautioned that global uncertainties - including shifting trade policies, geopolitical frictions, and financial market volatility - pose potential headwinds to exports, capital flows, and investor sentiment. "Notwithstanding these challenges, the confluence of well-anchored inflation expectations, sustained public capital expenditure, and firming rural and urban demand places the economy on a stable footing, positioning it to navigate emerging risks and preserve its growth momentum through the remainder of FY26," said the report published a day ahead of the second quarter GDP data release.The report said that various independent economic assessments place real GDP growth for Q2 FY26 in the range of 7.0-7.5%, indicating continued strength in underlying economic activity.It said the overall macroeconomic environment remains stable, supported by easing inflation, resilient domestic demand, and continued policy momentum. The favourable impact of GST rationalisation is increasingly visible in consumption indicators, while robust agriculture activity - reflected in the strong onset of Rabi sowing and adequate reservoir levels - has reinforced the outlook for food supply and rural incomes.The report said that corporate performance remains healthy, with sustained profitability and stable balance sheets.It said domestic financial markets continue to draw strength from firm institutional participation. "Meanwhile, the external sector remains shaped by a complex global environment, although the persistent strength in services exports provides an important counterbalance to the volatility in merchandise trade," said the report.It said the inflation outlook remains encouraging, supported by softening global commodity prices, benign energy markets, and targeted domestic supply interventions.
Article Summary: The economy enters the second half of FY26 on a stable footing, anchored by well-contained inflation, resilient domestic demand and supportive policy dynamics. The finance ministry report also cautioned that global uncertainties - including shifting trade policies, geopolitical frictions, and financial market volatility - pose potential headwinds.

Article Title: NPCI's BillPay arm to fix RBI's netbanking data gap
Article Text: MUMBAI: An arm of the National Payments Corporation of India has launched a platform that promises the RBI far greater oversight of net banking transactions, including payments linked to crypto or gaming.NPCI Bharat BillPay Limited has rolled out Banking Connect, an interoperable system that allows any merchant integrated through a payment aggregator to receive payments from all banks. "Today net banking operates as a mesh of bilateral ties between different merchants, payment aggregators and banks," said Noopur Chaturvedi, MD and CEO of NBBL. The new platform shifts the "heavy lifting" of managing multiple bank connections from merchants and aggregators to NBBL.Chaturvedi said that the RBI currently receives transaction data with a lag of at least a week, which stretches further when smaller banks are involved. Banking Connect aims to close that gap while offering banks faster and interoperable netbanking through a single switch that links all lenders and aggregators. The design is meant to improve success rates and reduce operational burdens. NBBL is targeting monthly transactions of 1 billion in four years, as against 260 million at presentThe system offers customers a mobile-first experience that supports biometric authentication and QR-based payments.Banks stand to gain from higher usage of their mobile apps, simpler technical integration compared with redirect flows, and tighter fraud controls.
Article Summary: NPCI Bharat BillPay Limited has rolled out Banking Connect. It allows any merchant integrated through a payment aggregator to receive payments from all banks. The new platform shifts the "heavy lifting" of managing multiple bank connections from merchants and aggregators to NBBL.

Article Title: Byju's Raveendran to file for $2.5bn damages, will appeal order
Article Text: NEW DELHI: Byju's founder Byju Raveendran is preparing to file a $2.5 billion damages claim, alongside new evidence in a US court that he says disproves Glas Trust's allegations that $533 million in 'alpha funds' was diverted by the company's founders.A US bankruptcy court had, in a default ruling last week, ordered Raveendran to pay more than $1 billion, saying the former corporate star, who set up the eponymous Indian edtech and tutoring company, had refused to cooperate with legal efforts to locate almost half the proceeds from a $1.2 billion US term loan made in 2021. Raveendran, however, contests the grounds, saying the court did not give him the 30 days he had sought to arrange a US attorney to argue the case. He vowed to appeal against the order and, in parallel, will bring a $2.5 billion damage suit against Glas Trust and those assisting it in a separate US court.He says the entire $533 million is fully accounted for, with the majority, $479.6 million, being routed from OCI - the loan arranger - to Revere Capital and then to Byju's entities and finally to Think & Learn Pvt Ltd (TLPL) - the parent company. TLPL used the money to pay for the $3 billion acquisitions, including Aakash Educational Services, in that year.This money trail, he says, has been established in documents Glas Trust served on Byju's for the legal proceedings in the US court. In a statement, Raveendran said he has also submitted a motion in the Delaware Bankruptcy Court, seeking correction of what he calls a premature damages determination. He argues that court mistakenly included a damages award as part of a sanction order for delayed document production, even though Glas Trust withdrew its request for a damages ruling in Sept and no liability was decided on the merits.
Article Summary: Byju's founder Byju Raveendran is preparing to file a $2.5 billion damages claim. He says new evidence disproves Glas Trust's allegations that $533 million in 'alpha funds' was diverted by the company's founders. A US bankruptcy court had, in a default ruling last week, ordered Rave endran to pay more than $1 billion.

Article Title: Expansion spree: Ikea plans to add 4-5 stores every year
Article Text: MUMBAI: Ikea is stepping up India expansion with plans to open four to five stores annually in the market where people are widening their budgets for home furnishing and decor, boosting growth prospects.This compares with all of six stores that the Swedish company launched in the country through the first seven years of its retail operations here. Patrik Antoni who took over as the India CEO in Aug said that Ikea has broadened its portfolio here, customised them to suit local nuances, built logistics network in major cities which helps it keep prices lower besides becoming more targeted in terms of the consumer cohorts they want to reach-strategies that have paid off and sets it up well for an aggressive expansion now.The company's sourcing business in India is way bigger than retail but Ikea is betting on the long-term opportunity that the market presents with a much younger demographic than its Western counterparts and population expansion in metros as more people migrate to bigger cities for jobs. "Now, we feel that we have a good base to take the leap forward. It's a big change. We won't build everything. It (store launches) will be through a mix of lease and own construction.The lease model enables faster expansion. We are looking for land to start more projects but nothing has been closed yet," Antoni said in an interview.Ikea competes with players such as Godrej Interio, Reliance Retail's Urban Ladder and Pepperfry in India. Local startups failed to grow in the market, eventually settling for acquisitions by other companies. Reliance Retail bought Urban Ladder in 2020 while Pepperfry that was once targeting a public debut was acquired by TCC Concept earlier this year. Ikea will open stores through a mix of formats in India with the expansion initially limited to six metros-Mumbai, Delhi-NCR, Pune, Chennai, Bengaluru and Hyderabad."This is because we have a solid logistical backbone in these cities. Efficiencies in distribution help to keep prices lower," said Antoni, shrugging off the idea of quick deliveries. "In all markets, it's one day delivery most of the time. We will try a bit with shorter windows (does not imply in minutes) to see if it gets any traction but people will rarely need a sofa (to give an example) in 10 minutes and I don't think it can be delivered in 10 minutes," Antoni said.Online channel is growing faster for Ikea-contributing over 25% of revenues but its focus will be to build an omni-channel play. "For us, online and offline go together. If we open a store in an area, online sales of that region grow," said Antoni. As it targets working professionals moving cities for jobs and nuclear families looking to spend on aesthetic spaces, Ikea is also betting big on food offerings.
Article Summary: Ikea has broadened its portfolio here, customised them to suit local nuances. The company's sourcing business in India is way bigger than retail. Ikea is betting on the long-term opportunity that the market presents with a much younger demographic than its Western counterparts.

Delhi Air Pollution Protest At India Gate Turns Violent Amid ‘Madvi Hidma Amar Rahe’ Slogans

(With agency inputs)

NEW DELHI: A thick layer of haze engulfed the national capital on Tuesday morning, with the Air Quality Index (AQI) remaining in the ‘very poor’ category across Delhi and the NCR, according to the Central Pollution Control Board (CPCB).A dense blanket of toxic smog covered central Delhi, including the India Gate area.At AIIMS and Safdarjung, the AQI stood at 323, while India Gate recorded an AQI of 328 — both falling under the ‘very poor’ category.Anand Vihar recorded a severe AQI level of 402, the highest among major monitoring points.In the ITO area, a thick layer of smog lingered as the AQI touched 380, also in the ‘severe’ category.The air quality is likely to be in the Very Poor category from November 23 to November 26 as per the the Air Quality Early Warning System (EWS) forecastAccording to AQI categorisation, 0-50 is 'good', 51-100 'satisfactory', 101-200 'moderate', 201-300 'poor', 301-400 'very poor', and 401-500 'severe'.The India Meteorological Department said the minimum temperature was expected to dip further to between 8°C and 10°C on Tuesday and Wednesday, and the maximum was likely to stay between 24°C and 26°C until Tuesday and possibly fall by another degree on Wednesday.Earlier, a total of 22 people were arrested for allegedly blocking a road, obstructing police, and using pepper spray on Delhi Police personnel during a protest at India Gate on Sunday against the rising air pollution in Delhi-NCR.Delhi Police on Monday said two FIRs have been registered in connection with the incident — one at Kartavya Path Police Station and another at Sansad Marg Police Station.At Kartavya Path Police Station, six male protesters were booked under BNS sections 74, 79, 115(2), 132, 221, 223, and 61(2). The second FIR, registered at Sansad Marg Police Station, names the remaining protesters, who have been charged under BNS sections 223A, 132, 221, 121A, 126(2), and 3(5).
Article Summary: A thick layer of haze engulfed the national capital on Tuesday morning. The Air Quality Index (AQI) remained in the ‘very poor’ category across Delhi and the NCR. Anand Vihar recorded a severe AQI level of 402, the highest among major monitoring points.

Article Title: What do new labour codes mean for employees & employers? From minimum wages, gratuity benefits to appointment letters & layoff rules
Article Text:
The new codes aim to increase women's employment opportunities, ensure worker safety, extend social security benefits to gig workers. (AI image)



Explained: How new labour laws could hit your take-home salary, increase your provident fund & gratuity contributions

These new labour codes will replace 29 existing labour laws. These codes are:

The Code on Wages, 2019

The Code on Social Security, 2020

The Occupational Safety, Health and Working Conditions Code, 2020

The Industrial Relations Code, 2020

Result of Rationalizing Labour Laws

What should employees know about the new labour codes?

There will now be separate classifications for 'employee' and 'worker', with different benefits allocated to each category.

A 'worker' means someone who belongs to the 'workman' category from the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, including individuals who perform manual, unskilled, skilled, technical, operational, clerical, or supervisory duties.

It excludes those in 'supervisory', 'managerial', or 'administrative' positions. Whilst the earlier legislation primarily addressed industrial disputes and retrenchment, the current definition has expanded considerably.

Workers will receive specific entitlements, including overtime compensation and leave encashment, as per the Occupational Safety, Health and Working Conditions Code, 2020. Regulations regarding working hours, annual leave, and standing orders apply specifically to 'workers'.

The codes bring in a unified 'wages' definition across all four sections. Earlier, multiple interpretations of 'wages' and 'salary' created difficulties in benefit calculations, which then resulted in inconsistencies and even legal disputes.

This 'wages' definition now applies to calculations for Gratuity, Employees' State Insurance, Leave Encashment, Overtime, Statutory Bonus, and other benefits. This standardisation aims to improve compliance through greater clarity.

Fixed term employees will get all benefits equal to permanent workers. This includes leave, medical, and social security. They will be eligible for gratuity after just one year, instead of the current five. Additionally, they will get equal wages as permanent staff, increasing income and protection.

To put it simply, gig workers and the unorganized sector will finally see social security benefits.

The new labour laws allow for companies that employ fewer than 300 workers to do layoffs and retrenchments without seeking prior governmental approval.

What are the key provisions of the new labour codes?

What do the new labour codes mean for employers?

Evaluate employment roles: Identify the employees who would qualify as ‘workers’ based on their substantial nature of work.

Identify the employees who would qualify as ‘workers’ based on their substantial nature of work. Assess the impact of the definition of ‘wages’ on employees’ salary structure: Review salary structure and benefits framework to comply with the new definition of ‘wages.’

Review salary structure and benefits framework to comply with the new definition of ‘wages.’ Analyze cost implications: Assess the financial impact of enhanced employee benefits on the organization.

Assess the financial impact of enhanced employee benefits on the organization. Reassess hiring models: Consider alternate hiring models in light of the provisions related to contract labour and fixed-term employment.

Consider alternate hiring models in light of the provisions related to contract labour and fixed-term employment. Align HR and Payroll policies: Ensure that HR and payroll processes comply with the labour codes and relevant state-specific regulations.

Ensure that HR and payroll processes comply with the labour codes and relevant state-specific regulations. Establish a robust compliance framework: Implement strong internal controls, conduct periodic diagnostic reviews, and ensure effective governance

New labour codes 2025: The Narendra Modi government has introduced what experts are calling a significant reform in labour laws with the implementation of four comprehensive labour codes. These codes are effective November 21, 2025. The new labour codes impact both employers and employees. The new laws mean some big benefits for workers - universal minimum wages, gratuity benefits, social security coverage, provisions for women to do night shifts, recognition of gig economy workers, formal appointment letter requirement etc. However, some provisions also raise employment security issues.The new codes aim to increase women's employment opportunities, ensuring worker safety, extending social security benefits to gig workers, and guaranteeing timely wage payments, while establishing minimum wage standards.At the same time, the new codes provide businesses increased operational flexibility whilst maintaining regulatory certainty, particularly important given current global economic challenges. Outdated labour laws have in the past deterred foreign investment in India's manufacturing sector, with companies often favouring countries like Vietnam and Bangladesh for their production facilities.Government officials indicated that rules for the four codes - covering wages, industrial relations, social security, and occupational safety and health - would be implemented within 45 days.Following their notification by 2020, the actual implementation had remained pending. The government has now officially announced the implementation. Whilst the final implementation rules from central and state governments are awaited, they are anticipated to be released soon.As Arvind Panagariya, Chairman of 16th Finance Commission wrote in TOI, “The importance of the four codes lies in breaking the ice. For the first time since the launch of reforms, they have removed the first set of hurdles in the way of creating high productivity jobs in large numbers.”These consolidated labour codes aim to streamline the existing laws, enhance digital compliance, improve workforce management systems, and strengthen worker protection along with facilitating business operations.EY is of the view that the implementation of the labour codes is a significant and long-awaited initiative by the government. “These codes are poised to impact nearly every function within organizations, given the extensive changes they introduce,” it says.“However, it may also result in increased costs for organizations due to wider scope of the definition of wages. There are still ambiguities regarding coverage of different components of salary within the definition of wages (such as coverage of performance bonuses / one-off payments, etc.),” notes EY in a note on the new Labour codes.The new labour laws restrict contract labour usage in organisations' 'core activities', barring specific exceptions. Core activity includes the main purpose of establishment creation and includes essential operations necessary for such activities.Additionally, fixed-term employment has received formal recognition as a legitimate employment arrangement, but it is contingent upon some conditions and regulatory requirements.The regulations also authorise states to implement adaptable work arrangements. Certain states, including Haryana and Odisha, have incorporated flexible working provisions in their draft regulations, permitting organisations to implement four-day work schedules, notes EY.EY notes that the labour codes significantly affect various aspects of HR and payroll policies. “Certain provisions overlap with existing state-specific Shops and Establishments laws, which are not superseded by the labour codes, potentially leading to conflicts, especially concerning working hours, leave, and related issues,” it says.Organizations operating in multiple states may have to ensure compliance with both sets of laws in each jurisdiction. Additionally, since specific provisions apply only to 'workers,' organizations may need to implement different policies for various employee categories, it adds.The new labour legislation also authorises both the central and state governments to create and execute welfare programmes for platform workers, gig economy participants, and unorganised sector employees.This can include life insurance, disability protection, healthcare provisions, maternity support, retirement security and any associated benefits.For gig worker social security arrangements, platform aggregators are required to contribute between 1-2% of their yearly turnover to the social security fund. This is subject to 5% of the amount paid or payable by an aggregator to gig workers, to the social security fund.This is a change from the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, which had set this limit at 100 workers. According to EY, the move offers businesses greater workforce management flexibility to adapt to market conditions.Additionally, the regulations also introduce a 're-skilling' fund to support any laid off workers in acquiring new skills. “For every retrenched worker, the employer is required to contribute 15 days’ last drawn wages (or any other amount notified by the central government) to a fund to be called the worker re-skilling fund,” explains EY.According to EY, It is essential for organizations to thoroughly assess the implications of these changes and prepare for a smooth transition to ensure compliance and operational efficiency. It suggests the following for organizations:The effectiveness of the new labour laws will substantially be dependent on state-level implementation, workforce education, and robust compliance monitoring.
Article Summary: The Narendra Modi government has introduced what experts are calling a significant reform in labour laws. The new codes aim to increase women's employment opportunities, ensure worker safety, extend social security benefits to gig workers. The codes are effective November 21, 2025.

Article Title: Rate call: ECB signals steady stance; policy minutes hint at openness to cuts next year
Article Text: The European Central Bank (ECB) sees interest rates as appropriately placed for now but has left room for potential cuts in 2026, according to minutes of its October meeting released on Thursday, AFP reported.The minutes showed that October’s unanimous decision to hold the key deposit rate at 2 per cent reflected broad agreement with Chief Economist Philip Lane’s view that inflation was under control. “Most measures of longer-term inflation expectations continued to stand at around two percent,” the minutes noted, adding that global economic activity showed signs of resilience.After two years of rate reductions, the ECB has kept rates unchanged for the past three meetings as inflation has retreated from a 2022 peak of 10.6 per cent to near the central bank’s two per cent target.However, concerns around slowing wage growth and subdued eurozone momentum — both weighing on inflation — have prompted some observers to anticipate rate cuts next year. The minutes confirmed that ECB members discussed the need to remain “entirely open-minded” about future easing.“While the economy was not so weak that it definitely implied an undershooting of the target over the medium term, it remained uncertain whether the economy had enough momentum to deliver the target,” the minutes said. They added that the governing council was “currently in a good place from a monetary policy point of view, though this should not be seen as a fixed place.”The ECB’s governing council will meet next on December 18, when it will unveil fresh economic projections extending for the first time to 2028.
Article Summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) sees interest rates as appropriately placed for now but has left room for potential cuts in 2026, according to minutes of its October meeting. The minutes confirmed that ECB members discussed the need to remain “entirely open-minded” about future easing.

Article Title: Chemical slump deepens: Wacker Chemie to cut 1,500 jobs; German sector hit by high energy costs and weak demand
Article Text:
Representative image

German chemical major Wacker Chemie on Thursday announced plans to cut 1,500 jobs, nearly a tenth of its global workforce, as the industry faces one of its toughest periods in decades.The company said most of the reductions will take place in Germany, with the process to be completed by the end of 2027, according to AFP.The job cuts form part of a broader plan to save more than 300 million euros ($348 million) annually. Wacker employs around 16,600 people worldwide, most of them based in Germany. Its customer base spans the automotive, construction and semiconductor sectors — all of which have been hit by slowing demand and rising competition.Shares of Wacker Chemie rose nearly 2 percent in Frankfurt after the announcement.Chief executive Christian Hartel said the operating environment for chemical firms in Germany needed urgent improvement. “The excessively high energy prices and bureaucratic obstacles continue to act as a central brake on the successful development of the chemical industry,” he said.The company had reported a net loss of more than 80 million euros in the third quarter, citing weak demand and mounting competition, particularly from China.Earlier this month, Germany’s VCI chemical industry association warned that production in the sector had slipped to a three-decade low, reflecting the broader strain on traditional industries as the country struggles to emerge from two years of recession.
Article Summary: Wacker Chemie announces plans to cut 1,500 jobs, nearly a tenth of its global workforce. The company said most of the reductions will take place in Germany, with the process to be completed by the end of 2027. The job cuts form part of a broader plan to save more than 300 million euros annually.

Article Title: Hong Kong high-rise fire: China Taiping shares slump on feared insurance exposure; disaster city's worst in decades
Article Text:
(Photo credit: AP)

Hong Kong Fire Out Of Control: Over 100 Casualties, Hundreds Missing; 3 Held For Manslaughter

China Taiping's insurance exposure



'Seriously underinsured'

China Taiping Insurance Holdings Co. shares fell sharply on Thursday amid concerns over its exposure to a Hong Kong construction project linked to a devastating high-rise fire that has killed at least 44 people and left hundreds missing.The stock slid as much as 8.1% in early trading before trimming losses to about 2% by late morning in Hong Kong. Firefighters continued battling the massive blaze on Thursday, nearly 18 hours after it tore through parts of the densely populated Wang Fuk Court estate in Tai Po.The disaster was the city's worst fire in decades, which erupted suddenly on Wednesday afternoon and rapidly engulfed several sections of the 32-storey complex, home to roughly 2,000 units.Authorities have arrested three men, saying flammable materials left behind during maintenance work had allowed the fire “to spread rapidly beyond control.”The buildings had been wrapped in bamboo scaffolding, a traditional but highly flammable material still widely used in Hong Kong.The fire began around 2:50 pm on Wednesday, with the estate under repair and wrapped in bamboo scaffolding, flames spread rapidly through the eight-building complex.The precise cause remains unknown, but officials believe leftover flammable material from maintenance work played a major role in the fire’s fast escalation. Rescue operations and investigations are ongoing.China Taiping underwrote third-party liability and employee compensation for mandatory building and window inspection work at the complex, Bloomberg reported.The HK$316 million (US$41 million) project, which used bamboo scaffolding and protective netting, is now part of an ongoing investigation into the cause of the disaster.The insurer’s policy covers the full contract sum plus an additional HK$50 million (US$6.4 million) for accidents, and provides HK$200 million in employee compensation. Separately, the company holds a general property-all-risk policy worth HK$2 billion.According to Bloomberg, Hong Kong Insurance Professionals Federation chairman Philip Mak said both the general all-risk policy and the construction-specific coverage are “seriously underinsured” given the scale of the multi-tower estate.Mak noted that rebuilding communal areas and replacing elevator steel cables will likely exceed the insured amounts. Individual flat owners may claim death or injury benefits under the HK$50 million accident portion, but he warned the sum is “nowhere near enough” in light of the number of deaths and the hundreds still unaccounted for.
Article Summary: China Taiping Insurance Holdings Co. shares fell sharply on Thursday amid concerns over its exposure to a Hong Kong construction project. The stock slid as much as 8.1% in early trading before trimming losses to about 2% by late morning in Hong Kong. China Taiping underwrote third-party liability and employee compensation for mandatory building and window inspection work.

Article Title: Asahi cyberattack: Japan's beer giant delays earnings; claims shipments resuming in stages as systems recover
Article Text: Japanese beer giant Asahi on Thursday delayed the release of its full-year financial results as it continues to grapple with a major cyberattack that began in late September."While the Company is making every effort to restore the system as quickly as possible, it has decided to postpone the announcement of financial results for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025," Asahi said in a statement.CEO Atsushi Katsuki added that product supply was gradually improving. "Regarding product supply, shipments are resuming in stages as system recovery progresses. We apologize for the continued inconvenience and appreciate your understanding," he added.Asahi, the maker of the popular Asahi Super Dry beer, first revealed on September 29 that it had been struck by a ransomware attack, becoming the latest global corporation to fall victim to such threats.Ransomware attacks involve hackers using malicious software to lock or encrypt systems and then demanding payment to restore access.The company has not disclosed the identity of the attackers or any demands made. However, hacker group Qilin believed to be based in Russia — issued a statement that Japanese media interpreted as a claim of responsibility.The attack on Asahi comes amid a wider wave of cyber incidents targeting major brands, AFP reported.Indian-owned Jaguar Land Rover recently sought emergency funding after a cyberattack disrupted operations at its UK factories, while Japanese retailer Muji halted its domestic online shopping service in October following a ransomware hit on its delivery partner Askul.
Article Summary: Asahi, maker of the popular Asahi Super Dry beer, first revealed on September 29 that it had been struck by a ransomware attack. Ransomware attacks involve hackers using malicious software to lock or encrypt systems and then demanding payment to restore access. Company has not disclosed the identity of the attackers or any demands made.

Article Title: Thanksgiving gift: Turkey prices fly, stores grounded; how bird flu outbreak is driving shortages, but not bills
Article Text:
Representational picture (AP photo)

The factors influencing turkey prices this Thanksgiving

Grocery stores in the US are absorbing the rising cost of turkeys this Thanksgiving. A spike in bird flu cases has pushed up wholesale prices, according to new data from the US department of agriculture (USDA). But these higher costs are not being passed on to shoppers.USDA figures show that advertised turkey prices in supermarkets are roughly the same as last year. Experts say stores are taking the hit to keep customers coming in, reported NBC News. Even the projected cost of a full Thanksgiving meal has stayed broadly steady.The main reason for the higher costs is a drop in supply. Bird flu has spread again among commercial poultry farms this autumn. By October, more than 2 million turkeys had been culled after exposure. Minnesota, the largest turkey-producing state, reported six confirmed outbreaks that month.David Ortega, a food economist at Michigan State University, told NBC, another virus avian metapneumovirus is also affecting production by reducing the number of viable eggs laid by hens. This has slowed farmers’ efforts to rebuild their flocks.Overall, turkey supply is tightening. The USDA expects production to fall to 4.8 million pounds this year, down from 5.1 million pounds in 2024.This shortage has pushed up costs for retailers. USDA data shows the wholesale price of frozen turkeys, the type most families buy for Thanksgiving, has jumped by about 80% since last year, rising from under $1 per pound to more than $1.70.A separate USDA report shows retail prices for frozen turkeys staying flat. Ortega said shops may be absorbing these increases to stop customers from switching stores. Retailers often use turkeys as a “loss leader”, selling them at or below cost to draw in shoppers and make up the difference through other items in their baskets.While turkey prices have stayed stable for shoppers, the overall cost of a Thanksgiving meal varies depending on the data source. Some estimates show prices rising by nearly 10%, while others show a fall of up to 5%.
Article Summary: USDA figures show that advertised turkey prices in supermarkets are roughly the same as last year. Even the projected cost of a full Thanksgiving meal has stayed broadly steady. The main reason for the higher costs is a drop in supply. Bird flu has spread again among commercial poultry farms this autumn.

Article Title: Asian stocks: Markets extend global rally on Fed cut bets; Japan's beer giant Asahi dips
Article Text: Asian stocks rose for a second straight session on Thursday, extending this week’s global rally as investors grow increasingly confident that the US Federal Reserve will deliver a third consecutive interest rate cut next month.The renewed optimism has pushed concerns over stretched valuations into the background for now, allowing risk appetite to strengthen across global trading floors — lifting equities and even riskier assets like bitcoin.Expectations for monetary easing have been reinforced by dovish comments from several Federal Reserve officials and a series of weaker-than-expected US jobs reports.Markets are now pricing in an around 80% chance of a rate cut on December 10, along with three more reductions in 2025 — compared with the three total cuts previously expected, according to Bloomberg.The Fed’s latest Beige Book also highlighted a widening split in consumer behaviour across the United States. “Overall consumer spending declined further, while higher-end retail spending remained resilient,” the report said, noting that some retailers were hit by the record-long government shutdown.Traders showed little reaction to fresh data showing jobless claims unexpectedly fell, bucking forecasts of a rise.All three major US indices closed higher for the fourth straight day on Wednesday, with Wall Street shut on Thursday for Thanksgiving.Asian markets followed the US gains with strong advances across major centres. Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei and Jakarta all traded higher. Wellington and Manila lagged.This upswing comes after markets stumbled earlier in the month over fears that the tech-driven surge of recent years had overheated, and returns from heavy AI investments would take time to materialise. For now, those concerns have been overshadowed by the prospect of lower borrowing costs, which are seen as a bigger support for a broader range of companies, including smaller caps.Bitcoin, which had slumped to a seven-month low just above $80,000 during the recent market turmoil, climbed back above $90,000 as risk appetite improved. The cryptocurrency remains well below its record high above $126,200 touched in early October.In corporate news, shares of Japan’s beer giant Asahi slipped after the company said it would delay its financial results due to a cyberattack that began in late September.The maker of Asahi Super Dry reported system troubles starting September 29, which disrupted its ability to receive orders and ship products. The company said the outage was caused by a ransomware attack.
Article Summary: Asian markets follow US gains with strong advances across major centres. Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, Taipei and Jakarta all traded higher. Wellington and Manila lagged. Bitcoin climbs back above $90,000 as risk appetite improves.

Article Title: US markets today: Wall Street extends gains as rate-cut hopes rise; tech stocks lead early rally
Article Text: US stocks climbed on Wednesday as Wall Street looked to stretch its winning run, buoyed by growing expectations of a Federal Reserve rate cut in December. According to AP, the S&P 500 rose 0.5% in early trade, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 227 points and the Nasdaq advanced 0.7%.Traders are pricing in nearly an 83% probability of a rate cut next month, CME Group data showed, after recent comments from Federal Reserve officials reinforced expectations of easing. AP reported that the S&P 500 is coming off three straight sessions of gains.Technology stocks led the rally. Dell Technologies rose 2.3% after reporting record demand for its artificial intelligence servers, while Nvidia — the market’s most valuable company — added 2.5%.Retailer Urban Outfitters surged 11.7% after posting earnings that beat Wall Street forecasts. Deere & Co., however, dropped nearly 4% after issuing a downbeat outlook that cited tariff pressures.The holiday-shortened trading week will see US markets closed on Thursday for Thanksgiving, with reduced hours on Friday.In the bond market, the yield on the 10-year Treasury inched up to 4.03%, while the 2-year yield rose to 3.49%.Global markets were broadly higher. Germany’s DAX gained 0.7% and France’s CAC 40 rose 0.6%, while Japan’s Nikkei 225 jumped 1.9% in a broad advance led by major exporters and technology counters.
Article Summary: The S&P 500 rose 0.5% in early trade, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 227 points and the Nasdaq advanced 0.7%. Traders are pricing in nearly an 83% probability of a rate cut next month, CME Group data showed.

Article Title: 'There is a Cisco': Why 'Big Short' investor Michael Burry is betting against Nvidia and Palantir
Article Text:
Why it matters



Zoom in: Burry’s beef isn’t with Nvidia’s books-but its customers’



The big picture: A new bubble with a familiar face



What they're saying: Nvidia responds, Burry doubles down



What’s next



Michael Burry, the investor famed for betting against the US housing market in “The Big Short,” is now shorting Nvidia and Palantir-two flagbearers of the AI rally. In a blistering Substack post, Burry dismissed Nvidia’s internal memo rebutting his concerns as “disingenuous on the face, and disappointing. ”He accused the world’s most valuable company of deflecting criticism with “one straw man after another,” charging that Nvidia’s response failed to engage with his actual concerns around depreciation assumptions in the AI ecosystem. The fresh attack comes as investors increasingly debate whether the AI boom has tipped into bubble territory, a Business Insider report said.The criticism comes at a critical moment: Nvidia stock has dropped 14% from its early-November peak, and broader questions are emerging over whether AI’s gold rush has entered speculative territory.Burry’s remarks tap into mounting investor unease-not about innovation, but about how profits are being propped up by accounting choices that may not age well as chip cycles shorten.Burry clarified that he never accused Nvidia of stretching out the depreciation of its own factories or equipment. “No one cares about Nvidia’s own depreciation,” he wrote. “One straw man burnt.”Instead, he zeroed in on cloud giants-Microsoft, Meta, Oracle-who are reportedly extending chip and server depreciation timelines from 3 years to 5 or 6.That, Burry says, lets them spread massive AI hardware costs over longer periods, inflating earnings now while kicking losses down the road.He cited a Microsoft interview in which Satya Nadella said the company slowed data center buildouts to avoid overbuilding for one generation of AI chips-a move Burry sees as confirmation that tech’s depreciation timelines may be out of sync with reality.“The hyperscalers have been systematically increasing the useful lives of chips and servers, for depreciation purposes,” Burry warned.Burry says today’s AI surge echoes the dot-com bubble-just with faster hardware, loftier assumptions, and bigger accounting risks. He compared Nvidia to Cisco circa 2000, the centerpiece of tech euphoria before the crash.“There is a Cisco at the center of it all,” he wrote. “Its name is Nvidia.”In a particularly stark forecast, Burry predicted tech companies could understate depreciation by $176 billion between 2026 and 2028, warning that Meta, Oracle and others could overstate earnings by 20–27% if timelines aren't adjusted.Nvidia disputed Burry’s math, especially around its stock buybacks. The company clarified that it has repurchased $91 billion in shares since 2018-not $112.5 billion as Burry implied-and said he mistakenly included RSU-related taxes.Nvidia also defended its GPU longevity, arguing chips like the A100 (released in 2020) are still in full use, justifying longer depreciation periods.Burry remains unmoved. “I stand by my analysis,” he posted on X. “Obviously, the full analysis does not fit in a tweet.”Burry disclosed he still holds put options on both Nvidia and Palantir, despite the market’s growing appetite for all things AI. He claimed they cost about $10 million each-not the $1.1 billion their notional value implied.He’s now using his new paywalled newsletter, “Cassandra Unchained,” to argue that this AI cycle isn’t just about tech-it’s also about the accounting scaffolding propping it up.“I have been drawn into something much bigger than me,” he wrote.If he’s right again, this won’t be the last straw man he sets alight.(With inputs from agencies)
Article Summary: Michael Burry, the investor famed for betting against the US housing market in ‘The Big Short,’ is now shorting Nvidia and Palantir. Burry’s beef isn’t with Nvidia's books-but its customers’ depreciation assumptions. He zeroed in on cloud giants-Microsoft, Meta, Oracle-who are reportedly extending chip and server depreciation timelines.

Article Title: Explained: How China gained rare earths dominance — and what it means for the US
Article Text:
AI image

Inside the rare earths hub of Ganzhou





US Turns to India to Curb China’s Rare Earth Grip, Global Alliance to Counter Beijing’s Moves

Why the US fell behind





America and allies search for alternatives





China’s control over rare earth elements did not happen overnight. It is the result of decades of investment across every stage of the chain — from mining and reserves to processing and technology — giving Beijing significant influence in its trade dispute with Washington.These 17 minerals are essential for defence equipment such as fighter jets, radar systems and missile guidance, and are also used in smartphones, medical tools and cars.According to news agency AFP reporters who visited Ganzhou this month, found the heavy rare earths region buzzing with activity despite tight surveillance.The area produces elements like yttrium and terbium, and the agency reporters witnessed trucks moving in and out of mines and busy processing plants.The city is also constructing new headquarters for China Rare Earth Group, one of two major state-owned players formed after years of government-led consolidation.Economics lecturer Heron Lim told AFP that recent disruptions have encouraged more countries to consider expanding their own production, adding that such moves “could pay longer-term dividends.”Trade tensions push rare earths to centre stageChina’s export restrictions announced in early October shook global manufacturers and alarmed Washington, which is locked in a renewed trade war with Beijing under President Donald Trump’s second term.After talks in South Korea, Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping agreed to a one-year truce that temporarily secures supplies of rare earths and other minerals — a development widely viewed as favourable to Beijing.Lim said rare earths would likely remain central to future negotiations, noting that China has shown it is prepared to use trade tools to keep the US engaged. He added that the uncertainty has created difficulties for industries dependent on these metals.During the Cold War, the United States led the rare earths industry, with the Mountain Pass mine in California supplying much of the world.But as relations with Moscow improved and environmental concerns grew, the US shifted production overseas through the 1980s and 1990s.China now accounts for about two-thirds of global mining and roughly 90% of processing, according to analysis cited by AFP. It also holds the world’s largest reserves and leads in patents, supported by strict export controls on processing technology.Commodities analyst Amelia Haines was quoted by AFP as saying that the heavy reliance on imports poses “significant risks to critical industries,” which could accelerate a broader push for mineral security.The US has been attempting for years to rebuild its rare earths capacity. Defence agencies have invested heavily to establish a full “mine-to-magnet” chain by 2027.Washington has also signed critical minerals agreements with allies including Australia, Japan, Malaysia and Thailand.Trump recently announced an $8.5 billion rare earths partnership with Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese.This urgency is not new. In 2010, China briefly halted rare earth shipments to Japan during a territorial dispute, highlighting the geopolitical stakes.The Obama administration called for strengthening US resilience, yet 15 years on, China remains the dominant force in the sector.
Article Summary: China's control over rare earth elements did not happen overnight. It is the result of decades of investment across every stage of the chain. China now accounts for about two-thirds of global mining and roughly 90% of processing. It also holds the world’s largest reserves and leads in patents.

Article Title: Budget leak shock: UK's Treasury chief Reeves unveils tax plan in Parliament; Labour braces for political fallout
Article Text: Britain’s Treasury chief Rachel Reeves delivered her tax-raising budget on Wednesday under the shadow of a major leak that exposed her proposals hours before she reached Parliament. The disclosure came from the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), which Reeves relies on for independent forecasts. According to AP, the leak effectively mapped out the entire fiscal package.The OBR said a “technical error” caused the documents to go live early on its website and apologised for the breach, adding that it would report the lapse to all relevant authorities, including the Treasury. AP reported that the biggest revenue measure is a freeze on tax thresholds that will push more earners into higher bands as wages rise.Other announcements flagged in the leaked papers include a mansion tax on high-value properties, changes to the capital tax regime and a reduction in tax-free allowances for private pensions. The documents estimate that the government will raise 26 billion pounds ($34 billion) in 2029–30.The episode has embarrassed the Labour government, which has already been grappling with weeks of speculation and mixed signals that unsettled financial markets.This is Reeves’ second budget since Labour’s landslide return to power in July 2024.Reeves repeated that her overall message remains unchanged from her first budget, when she said there would be only one major tax-raising exercise this parliamentary term, which runs to 2029. But the UK economy has struggled to match her expectations, with critics pointing to last year’s business tax increases as a drag.Although Britain briefly led the G7 in growth during the first half of the year, momentum faded again. “The chancellor faces a delicate balancing act of conveying fiscal stability while advancing the growth agenda,” said Peter Arnold, chief economist at EY UKBritain’s long struggle to recover from the 2008–09 financial crisis continues to weigh on tax revenues. Those pressures have been compounded by the economic costs of the pandemic, the Russia–Ukraine war and US President Donald Trump’s global tariffs, with Brexit adding additional strain since 2020.Reeves also faces a raft of spending promises aimed at easing the cost of living as inflation remains elevated. Measures include reversing planned welfare cuts, reviewing the cap on benefits for larger families and offering relief through frozen rail fares or lower green taxes on energy bills.The political stakes are high for Reeves and Prime Minister Keir Starmer, who is battling concern within Labour over his poor poll numbers. Surveys consistently place Labour behind Nigel Farage’s Reform UK. With an election not required until 2029, the government is banking on stronger growth to improve its standing, but analysts warn that a misjudged budget could deepen the sense of crisis around Starmer’s leadership.
Article Summary: Treasury chief Rachel Reeves delivered her tax-raising budget on Wednesday under the shadow of a major leak. The disclosure came from the Office for Budget Responsibility (OBR), which Reeves relies on for independent forecasts. The OBR said a “technical error’ caused the documents to go live early on its website.

Article Title: Inflation? Why Thanksgiving is cheaper this year (and what that says about the economy)
Article Text:
The turkey got cheaper, not the world



Retailers are buying your gratitude



The feast is cheaper, the sides are sulking



Farmers were not invited to this celebration



Politics of the poultry index



The Costco shortcut and the new definition of convenience



what dishes count as “standard”,

how many portions they define as “normal”,

what ingredients get included or excluded,

how much profit margin they can hide in the bundle.

Cheap thanks, expensive future



Retailers are deliberately discounting turkey as a loss leader to attract shoppers.

Wholesale costs have not collapsed, meaning the discount is a financed illusion.

Some key food categories — especially grains — have cooled, reducing the cost of specific items.

Other categories — vegetables, fruits, beverages — remain expensive.

Consumers have traded down to store brands, frozen pies and smaller menus.

Farmers are facing higher costs and lower margins.

Inflation is slowing, not reversing.

Politicians are selling a narrative more than a macroeconomic reality.

For a country that once launched a revolution over the price of tea, America gets remarkably sentimental about the cost of turkey. Every November, economists, politicians and supermarket executives gather around a metaphorical table to debate the national poultry index, as if the fate of the republic depends on whether a 16-pound bird costs twenty dollars or twenty-five.This year, for the first time in a while, that conversation contains a four-letter word that Americans haven’t heard in a long time: down. The Thanksgiving dinner is officially cheaper. But the story of why it is cheaper is far more interesting than the number itself. It’s a tale of retail psychology, farmer misery, supply chain politics, and the great American tradition of pretending a discount is the same thing as prosperity.Let’s begin with the headline. The average cost of the classic Thanksgiving dinner for ten has dipped a few percentage points. The centrepiece of this softened inflation narrative is the turkey. A standard bird is significantly cheaper this year — the sharpest drop in years — and it has lowered the overall cost of the meal.But here’s the real twist: the world around that turkey is still expensive. Food-at-home prices remain elevated compared to pre-pandemic levels.Everyday staples like cereals, fresh vegetables, condiments and beverages are still inching upward. Grocery bills are not collapsing. They are simply not rising as brutally as they did in 2022 and 2023.Think of Thanksgiving as the supermarket’s Bollywood song-and-dance sequence. Eighty per cent of the movie is gritty realism. But for five minutes, everyone forgets their troubles and celebrates because the turkey looks cheap.Why is the turkey cheap if the world is not? Simple. Retailers are taking the hit.In the supermarket playbook, the Thanksgiving turkey is the emotional equivalent of “free delivery”. It’s a loss leader — the product a store sells at or below cost to drag you inside and make sure you buy everything else at full price.Grocery giants know that Americans treat Thanksgiving like a ritual. You must buy the turkey. You must buy the sides. You must buy the extras. The only question is where. And that is where the retail war begins.Several major chains are deliberately discounting turkeys even though their own acquisition costs have gone up. Wholesale prices have risen due to disease outbreaks in turkey flocks and feed costs that haven’t come down nearly enough. But supermarkets are absorbing that pain because the turkey discount is an unbeatable form of customer acquisition.Tech companies give free trials. Supermarkets sacrifice poultry margins.And as every business student learns on day one: customer eyeballs today are worth more than profit margins this week.This “cheaper Thanksgiving” narrative also depends heavily on what you choose to count.Turkey and wheat-based products — bread, buns, pie crusts — have become cheaper thanks to slightly better global crop cycles and softer consumer demand. Frozen items, store brands and bulk packs have also become more popular, forcing retailers to compete on price.But vegetables? Those are having an existential crisis. Weather disruptions in key growing regions have hit sweet potatoes and green beans. Basic vegetable trays have shot up in price in many parts of the country. Fresh fruit is pricier thanks to transportation and import pressures. Canned goods, especially those dependent on metal and packaging costs, are not giving any Thanksgiving discounts.So yes, the meal looks cheaper. But it is the turkey that is doing the heavy lifting while half the sides are quietly sulking in the corner, waiting for someone to notice their suffering.If there is one group that does not feel thankful this year, it is the American farming community.Consumers see the downturn in the cost of the Thanksgiving basket. Farmers see a very different ledger. Crop prices for some staples have declined, but their input costs haven’t. Fertiliser, fuel, machinery and labour remain stubbornly high. Weather shocks — drought, heat waves, erratic rains — continue to disrupt yields unpredictably.Turkey farmers, in particular, have been hammered. Outbreaks of avian flu have led to culling entire flocks after a single infection. One diseased bird means a financial disaster for a farmer who spent months raising hundreds. Retailers can afford to discount a turkey. Farmers cannot afford to lose one.The Thanksgiving discount that consumers are celebrating is made possible partly because someone else is swallowing pain higher up the supply chain.This is not a moral argument. It is a business one. Retailers compress margins aggressively. Farmers have no margins left to compress. Inflation did not leave. It simply dressed up as generosity. This is the part where inflation performs one of its favourite magic tricks: anchoring.After years of high inflation, consumers have adjusted their expectations upwards. So when a $64 Thanksgiving meal becomes a $55 meal, it feels like a relief — even if the same dinner cost far less just a few years ago. This is not victory. It is relief masquerading as recovery.And retailers exploit this psychology brilliantly. A sharply discounted, culturally significant product creates a narrative of “things are finally getting better”. Meanwhile, dozens of other items around the store have quietly gone up by 2 to 10 percent. You notice the cheap turkey. You do not notice the expensive soda, the quietly inflated butter, or the premium packaging costs.In business terms, the turkey is the shiny notification. Everything else is the terms and conditions.Any national holiday with food and numbers will inevitably be hijacked by politics. Thanksgiving is no exception.Cheap turkey prices become evidence of economic competency. Expensive turkey prices become evidence of national collapse. Every White House, regardless of party, loves claiming credit for a “cheaper Thanksgiving”, even when the primary drivers are retail strategy, not government policy.This year, politicians have repeated the line that the Thanksgiving meal is significantly cheaper. They highlight the change from last year. They do not highlight the change from 2018 or 2015, because that comparison is far less flattering.The turkey aisle becomes a political prop. The optics serve everyone. Retailers get attention. Politicians get talking points. Consumers get the illusion of victory.Everyone wins the narrative. No one wins the economics.There’s another emerging trend: the pre-assembled Thanksgiving meal. Big box retailers now offer complete kits that feed families for less than the average DIY cost.On the surface, this looks like efficiency and savings. Underneath, it is something else entirely.When you outsource your Thanksgiving meal to a corporation, the company gains power over:Software companies call this bundling. Economists call it controlling the supply chain. Grandma calls it “not my Thanksgiving”.Think of it as the Netflix-ification of holiday meals. A corporation decides the menu. You just show up and hit play.So why exactly is Thanksgiving cheaper this year?Let’s strip away the marketing and look at the mechanics:This year’s Thanksgiving is not proof that the economy is healed. It is proof that retailers are very good at narrative management. The Thanksgiving basket is a PR campaign wrapped in aluminium foil.It is also a case study in how the American consumer economy works. When inflation rages, retailers raise prices. When inflation softens, retailers lower selective prices and call it generosity. When the economy is jittery, the turkey becomes a bargaining chip in a much larger psychological war for customer loyalty.And here is the final irony.Americans will sit around their tables this November and give thanks for a slightly cheaper meal. But the price cut is not the result of a benevolent market, a miraculous supply chain recovery or a sudden burst of federal competence.It is the result of carefully calibrated retail economics. Someone decided that your gratitude was worth a discounted bird. Someone else — usually a farmer — paid for that gratitude out of their own margins. And the rest of the store quietly made back what the turkey lost.The turkey may be cheaper. The world around it is not. But in a year where everything feels a bit fragile, America will take the small win. Even if it is cooked, seasoned and packaged to perfection by the marketing department.
Article Summary: The average cost of the classic Thanksgiving dinner for ten has dipped a few percentage points. A standard bird is significantly cheaper this year — the sharpest drop in years. But here’s the real twist: the world around that turkey is still expensive.

Article Title: US–China trade thaw? Beijing buys $300 million in US soybeans after Donald Trump–Xi Jinping phone call: Report
Article Text:
File photo: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping (Picture credit: PTI)

Xi Tells Trump 'TAIWAN MUST RETURN TO CHINA' As Tensions Over Japan PM Takaichi's Remarks Snowball

China has purchased at least 10 cargoes of US soybeans, worth around $300 million, in contracts signed since Tuesday, sources quoted by news agency Reuters claimed.The deals come a day after US President Donald Trump spoke with his Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping, signalling a thaw in trade relations between the two countries.Each cargo ranges between 60,000 and 65,000 metric tons, with shipments scheduled for January from Gulf Coast terminals and the Pacific Northwest.Trump, commenting on the renewed engagement, said he had urged Xi to accelerate and increase China’s purchases of American goods, adding that the Chinese leader had “more or less agreed,” reported Reuters.The purchases extend a surge in Chinese buying following late-October talks in South Korea and reflect efforts to stabilise bilateral dialogue on trade.Despite US soybeans being priced higher than Brazilian alternatives, China paid premiums of $2.3 per bushel over the January Chicago futures contract for Gulf shipments and $2.2 per bushel for Pacific Northwest cargoes, compared with around $1.8 per bushel for Brazilian supplies.Johnny Xiang, founder of Beijing-based AgRadar Consulting, was quoted by Reuters as saying, “Commercial buyers will continue to avoid US soybean imports, as prices remain higher than Brazilian beans.At these levels, crush margins are not financially viable.”State-run COFCO has led the recent buying spree, securing nearly 2 million tons of US soybeans since late October, as per Reuters.While these deals fall short of the 12 million tons previously announced by the White House, US treasury secretary Scott Bessent said the purchases are “right on schedule,” citing a broader agreement for China to buy 87.5 million tons of American soybeans over the next three-and-a-half years.Trump and Xi’s phone call on Monday addressed a wide range of issues, including trade, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, fentanyl controls, and agricultural products like soybeans.Trump expressed optimism about bilateral cooperation, saying, “I think we will be pleasantly surprised by the actions of President Xi. I have a great relationship with him. I like him. He likes me… He invited me to visit Beijing in April, which I accepted”.
Article Summary: China has purchased at least 10 cargoes of US soybeans, worth around $300 million, in contracts signed since Tuesday. Each cargo ranges between 60,000 and 65,000 metric tons, with shipments scheduled for January from Gulf Coast terminals and the Pacific Northwest.

Article Title: US fiscal strain: Deficit jumps to $284 billion despite record tariffs; shutdown delays and debt costs deepen gap
Article Text:
File photo (Picture credit: AP)

FULL: ‘AMERICANS, DON’T FORGET!’: Trump ROASTS Dems, ENDS Shutdown, Wants Filibuster Gone | Watch
